ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the important of east Asian art & a bunch of interesting ways art informs our understanding of history.

I gained a new understanding of both pre- and modern art. I now know more about popular motifs used in artistic traditions across the continent, particularly in Buddhist art. As a non-art major, I improved my skills at observing and writing about art analytically.
An introduction to Asian art.
I learned a lot about East Asian history and art. I learned about how to do research on this discipline too and how to approach a piece of art in terms of analysis.
I gained a comprehensive understanding of Asian art history, as well as a good review of the historical context of those artworks. I also learned how to visually analyze art.

I learned about the connections between different regions in East Asia, from prehistoric art to contemporary. This course taught me how to connect different pieces of art across time and space, and I also gained knowledge about the cultural history of each region we studied.
Overview of Asian art history, vocabulary to discuss art, more background as to how art is created
I became much more observant and felt that my ability to analyze art greatly improved. I also learned so much about Asian culture and how to identify it in many different forms of artwork.
Basic understanding of East Asian art history
This was my first lecture-style course. I learned how to take efficient notes.
general overview of Asian art
It was actually a strinkingly good introduction to religion in Asia as well as art.
overview of art history in East Asia

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: range of content, reasonable assignments
Weakness: not really any weakness

STRENGTHS: trips to the art gallery that helped keep students engaged with the works, guest speakers to offer insight into different roles within the art world, varied topics that allowed for a diversity of discussion, cohesive lesson plan that flowed well between lessons, interesting assignments that made students think creatively about assignments rather than regurgitating information.

WEAKNESSES: N/A
Lectures were very surface level but understandable, since this was an intro course. Quincy is a very passionate professor!

Professor Ngan put together very well-organized and engaging lectures. The assignments were also broad enough to encourage exploration, but were not too overwhelming. It was also cool to look at pieces of art during sections. The only weakness I would note is that I wish our sections would have involved walking through the art gallery, as opposed to just looking at pieces in the basement.

I think the lectures could be structured a little better to remind us of the key points or main topics that we are supposed to retain. Some of the readings didnt feel related to the class, so I wish there was a bit more connection between readings and class. I think this class is really strong in how receptive the TFs and the Professor are and how they are eager to receive and act on feedback. Halfway through this semester, there was a Poorvu center review of the course, and the Professor definitely acted on the feedback which improved the course. Its a fun class.

Quincy is a very passionate lecturer, even at 9:25 in the morning, and his lecture slides were well organized. The discussion sections were also very fun; it was to be able to interact closely with YUAG objects.

I loved looking at the art pieces in person during section and discussing them with my classmates. I also thought Professor Quincy told really interesting stories in his lectures instead of just showing us the pieces and the facts about them. They felt like components of historical narratives, rather than the narratives being background facts for the art. I would have appreciated a little more guidance/more explanation on the first assignment (the research paper proposal); I wasn't exactly sure what was expected of me until after I got the comments back.

It's difficult because this is an EXTREMELY broad survey that really does an injustice to the many regions it covers. Asia is a huge continent!! I would've preferred maybe four instead of five topics as we could've then covered them in more depth. As someone of Indian descent I would sacrifice that topic because Quincy didn't seem to excited to teach that material for some reason.
Strengths: the material was very fascinating and the professor was great. Weakness: the professor often read off of his own script and did not include a lot of information on his slides

Due to the broad amount of material lumped into the course, you learn about representative art pieces from the region / time period but don't get to see a broad selection. It's a strength that students are exposed to so much, but it is also a weakness in that little depth is possible, although the instructor did a fantastic job considering the limitations.
I thoroughly enjoyed this class. Any weakness that I initially had were answered and applied during the midsemester feedback.

Strengths: content format, assignments
Weaknesses: lectures aren't super engaging
I think the course would be benefited by more closely discussion the readings in the TF sections. I felt that it was a good intro class but fairly surface level.
The lectures are sometimes difficult to follow; they also move quickly. The reading is super manageable and always interesting. Professor Quincy is very enthusiastic and kind.

strengths: very passionate lecturer, also nice to see artwork discussed in lecture up close in section 
weaknesses: lecture can be a bit hard to follow, lots of information crammed into one lecture
more efficient sections. lectures were really good

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! If you want a relaxing way to learn about East Asian art, this course is a great opportunity

Absolutely! It is a great course, especially if you are just starting to get into art history or just want to take a class out of interest. Prof. Ngan made sure it was very accessible to non-art history majors and engaging for all. We had multiple sections take place in the Yale Art Museum with the objects that we learned about in class. The two independent assignments (attend a talk and write short report and Wikipedia page proposal/final project) were really interesting and I actually found myself completing them well before the deadline because I enjoyed it. The prof really lets you take charge of your project. We also got days off where Prof/TAs were around to ask questions when there was a major assignment due, so we would have time to work on it, which was very helpful. Overall it was my favorite class this semester because I felt like I learned a lot about an underrepresented field without worrying about punitive grading or needing to become an expert. Would recommend to anyone and everyone.
Yes! Quincy is very engaging.
Yes! It is a very encouraging and low stakes environment in which one can explore a really fascinating topic.
Yes! It's a fun course that teaches you both history and visual analysis with a very doable workload (and very passionate TAs).

Yes! I thought the material was super interesting, especially the contemporary art at the end of the course. I also think the opportunity to look at the objects in the YUAG was really cool. The course wasn't too difficult, but it was intellectually stimulating and I genuinely enjoyed going to lectures.

Sure. I saw some cool art but at the end of the day, because the course material was so broad, I felt like I just scratched the surface. Take History of Decorative Arts if you're looking for an intro for the major.
Yes! If you're looking for a fun class to take in addition to some of your heavier major courses, this is great.

Yes! It was a great intro art history class for someone with no background who wants more exposure to art. I learned a lot, not only about class content, but about lecture series on campus and the YUAG collections.
Yes, this course was very enjoyable and eye-opening to anyone with an appreciation for art.
The lectures aren't very engaging but the content is interesting and the workload is very easy. Also section assignments are interesting and relevant to the topic.
I would recommend for a student looking for an introduction to art historical thinking.
If you are interested in Asian art or culture, then absolutely. The course was interesting and quite easy. We also engaged with the YUAG a ton which was fun.
yes, if they want a good introduction to asian art
Definitely take it for a relatively low stakes way to get exposed to the material. The feeling of genuinely improving the internet with the final project is nice too.
Yes
yes very interesting content and professor is great lecturer
